body:
Thanks for the response. However, I did not understand the need for a metric in Filter box. Cant we do a simple distinct for each filter option? Also I agree with additional config elements for each filter. Such as allow single choice vs multi choice. Radio box, Check box, etc.

Thanks

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/12729672/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/12729672)

Changes Unknown when pulling **8fa4b2b0b03006da087dbc4241dca26cc0de66de on graceguo-supercat:gg-SlicesTemplate** into ** on apache:master**.
This will be useful if we can define it in the JSON metadata where we can add preselect_filters and hence define default filter set.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/12730774/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/12730774)

What command are you using to install Superset? `pip install superset`? 

Flask gets installed through `flask_appbuilder`, which may specify a version range and I'd prefer let them specify it. Maybe the issue happens only if `flask_wtf` installs before `flask_appbuilder`?
LGTM, want me to merge it since you don't have write access [yet]?

It's unclear to me what you mean by "display the top '5' departments by revenue across years , months and quarter". What type of visualization? time series? a table?

And yes you can use custom queries as input. The easiest way is to click [Visualize] from a SQL Lab result set.
Not at the moment, the heatmap clearly needs some work...
This PR doesn't look right... 76 files changed?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/12734961/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/12734961)

The metric can be nice as it sorts the values based on the metric. Say if we have a filter on the "Market" dimension at Airbnb it would show the biggest markets on top.
Would that be a pyhive issue or a Spark Thrift server implementation issue?
@vibinsv09 you're right, it should be easy to squeeze that feature into the dashboard's JSON metadata as `default_filter` or something

did you install mysql with `pip install mysqlclient` before running? and ur mysql connection string should be in `mysql://username:password@host:port/dbname` format.

looking at the message `no manifest file found at /usr/local/projects/incubator-superset/superset/static/assets/dist/manifest.json` it doesn't seem like you are using as venv as you claim. I'd expect to see `site-packages` somewhere in there

Maybe leftover from a previous install?
Made a bit of progress but I need more time. The query API is tricky because it's so rich and flexible.

With the command line:
```
(venv) abannin@macbook-pro:/usr/local/projects/incubator-superset$ 
(venv) abannin@macbook-pro:/usr/local/projects/incubator-superset$ superset runserver
Starting server with command: 
gunicorn -w 2 --timeout 60 -b  0.0.0.0:8088 --limit-request-line 0 --limit-request-field_size 0 superset:app

[2017-08-07 22:44:27 -0700] [60162] [INFO] Starting gunicorn 19.7.1

```

@mistercrunch 
It is going to be hard with 
> no scroll on the lower right  

On the lower right many tabs have `react-virtualized` which[ doesn't support scroller on the nesting element out of the box](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45553667/how-to-add-a-scroller-to-the-nesting-element-of-the-react-virtualize-table).  
We could create our own component for that, or try to extend [react-virtualized](https://github.com/bvaughn/react-virtualized).  
Either way it seems to be a separate big task.

Another one possible solution would be to have one common scroller for the page. Instead of two separate scrollers for the two columns we have.

We could also go the [jsfiddle way](https://jsfiddle.net/). it is simply not possible to extend anything there so, that some part of the page goes beyond the screen.

@surya2012 there is currently a problem with autogenerated metrics when you add a new BigQuery datasource – the generated SQL expressions for these metrics contain dataset, e.g. `SUM(dataset.table.column)`. You need to manually remove dataset and just leave a table and a column, e.g. `SUM(table.column)` and it should be working.
@mxmzdlv Thank you.. It is working when I removed dataset manually . :)
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3262 should unblock this effort

Hi Maxime,

Thanks for merging the PR. When looked online for similar issues, the closest one I can find is this one:
https://github.com/pallets/flask/issues/1106
They solve it by including `Flask>=0.10.1` as a dependancy so the `flask_appbuilder` can still decide on the version. Personally I would recommend to pin the version, this makes debugging easier because everyone is running the same version of Flask.

To get back to your question, I do not use `pip install superset`, but I build it from source [as described](https://superset.incubator.apache.org/installation.html#making-your-own-build):
```
apt-get update \
&& apt-get install -y npm git build-essential libssl-dev libffi-dev libsasl2-dev libldap2-dev nodejs-legacy python-dev python-pip \
&& pip install --upgrade setuptools pip \
&& npm install -g npm@'>=5.0.3' \
&& git clone https://github.com/Fokko/incubator-superset.git $SUPERSET_HOME \
&& cd $SUPERSET_HOME/superset/assets \
&& npm install \
&& npm run build \
&& cd $SUPERSET_HOME \
&& python setup.py install
```
This is happening in a clean Docker ubuntu image.

Cheers, Fokko
